categories.title: Building Trust
definition: Communicates transparently, demonstrating sound judgement and reasoning; promotes transparency across their area of responsibility
Demonstrates care for the well-being, interests, and success of others; creates an environment where others can do the same
Models personal reliability and accountability; driving systems that assign clear responsibility for important objects and ensures accountability acreoss the function

subjects.title: Trusted Partner Leadership Intention Workshop
subjects.description: Through reflective activities and open discussions, attendees will explore the intricacies of trust-building, identify personal trust anchors and wobbles, and strategize ways to authentically model trust-centric behaviors across diverse team settings.

subjects.title: Begin with Trust
subjects.description: This article explains how leaders can identify their weaknesses and strengths on these three dimensions and offers advice on how all three can be developed in the service of a truly empowering leadership style.

subjects.title: Failure Spectrum: Strategies for Learning from Failure
subjects.description: In this article, learn to recognize that failure is inevitable in today's complex work organizations, however some failures are even good. Successful learning from failure is not simple: It requires context-specific strategies. First leaders must understand how the blame game gets in the way and must work to create an organizational culture in which employees feel safe admitting or reporting on failure.  Learn about the different types of failures and how to learn from each.

subjects.title: Special Issue: How to Build Trust (Skill Path)
subjects.description: Dive into this MyLearning skill plan on building trust. Learn more about how to cultivate relationships with customers and colleagues, win over skeptics, and inspire others through these curated resources.

categories.title: Agility
categories.description: Change is constant. Sharpen your ability to respond productively to changing circumstances and function effectively in ambiguous conditions.
definition: Responds productively to changing circumstances, undeterred by failure
Demonstrates resilience in the face of changing environment and circumstances
Functions as effetively under conditions of ambiguity as when things are more certain

subjects.title: How Adaptive Strategy Happens
subjects.description: The article underscores the need for flexible strategic planning in organizations, comparing it to sailing and suggesting practices like defining an Essential Intent, setting strategic trade-offs, and identifying 90-day outcomes. It concludes by advocating for organizations to operate as adaptable fleets rather than large, inflexible cruise ships.

subjects.title: Cultivating Mental Agility
subjects.description: In today's rapidly changing world, we need to challenge conventional thinking to become efficient problem solvers and decision makers. Dorie Clark's course emphasizes the importance of mental agility for career growth and company relevance, covering resilience building, learning from past experiences, and creating a culture that can adapt to change.

subjects.title: Geopolitical Risk - Navigating a world in flux
subjects.description: In a fast-fragmenting world, geopolitical instability has vaulted to the top of the CEO agenda. Here’s what today’s fraught global dynamics mean for leaders—and how they can begin grappling with geopolitical risk successfully.

subjects.title: Building Resilience as a Leader
subjects.description: This course by psychologist and executive coach, Gemma Leigh Roberts, focuses on resilience as a key attribute for successful leadership. It provides practical strategies to develop resilience, enabling individuals to tackle challenges, lead effectively, and build robust teams and organizations that can withstand risks and change, particularly useful for busy leaders navigating challenging times.

subjects.title: Strategic Agility
subjects.description: Gary Bolles' course discusses the need for adaptive strategies in today's fast-paced, ever-changing work environment. It guides organizational leaders on how to become an adaptive organization, touching on key aspects like hiring decisions, company values, process alignment, risk management, and the behaviors that senior leaders should exemplify

categories.title: Decision Making
categories.description: Good leaders make good decisions. But efficient and inclusive decision-making processes take time and practice.
definition: Leads the decision-making process by adopting the decision-making framework, gathering the right data and avoiding consensus
Selects the best choice among available alternatives by seeking alternate perspectives, demonstrating openness to divergent viewpoints, and understanding broader implications
Communicates decision rationale, builds alignment around decisions among critical stakeholders, and escalates appropriately

subjects.title: Speed as a Habit
subjects.description: All things being equal, speed will determine whether your company succeeds or not. Here's how to make it core to your culture.

subjects.title: Even/Over Statements: The Prioritization Tool That Brings Your Strategy to Life
subjects.description: The article introduces 'Even/Over' statements as a tool to prioritize one aspect over another for improved decision-making and strategic edge in business, with successful examples from Airbnb and In-N-Out Burger, and outlines a method to define these statements within teams to foster aligned autonomy and scale effective decision-making.

subjects.title: 7 Strategies for Better Group Decision-Making
subjects.description: The article discusses the benefits and pitfalls of group decision-making, highlighting the risk of groupthink and biases. It recommends seven behavioral science-backed strategies to enhance group decision-making, including keeping the group small, encouraging diversity, appointing a devil’s advocate, collecting independent opinions, creating a safe speaking environment, not over-relying on experts, and sharing collective responsibility for outcomes.

subjects.title: Making Key Decisions as a Manager
subjects.description: In this course, management expert Kevin Eikenberry guides managers on effective decision-making, distinguishing key decisions from others, and the impact of these decisions on people and processes. He presents different decision-making approaches, considerations for critical decisions, and how to implement and communicate these decisions effectively. The course aims to boost decision-making confidence, leading to better outcomes for the organization and team, and enhancing chances of success.

subjects.title: Decision-Making in High Stress Situations
subjects.description: In this course, Becki Saltzman teaches how to use stress as an advantage in decision-making, especially during crises. She provides techniques to discover hidden options, evaluate potential outcomes, avoid consensus-driven decision pitfalls, and make sound judgment calls. The course aims to help prevent stress from hindering effective decision-making.

categories.title: Empathic & Inclusive Leadership
categories.description: One “mind” doesn’t fit all. Bring out the best in your team by leading with cultural intelligence that is open to divergent perspectives.
definition: Leads with a global mindset and cultural intelligence
Models empathy, humility, courage, and vulnerability
Display curiosity and sincere desite to understand other's perspectives, and seeks out divergent points of view, especially when making decisions

subjects.title: The Key to Inclusive Leadership
subjects.description: Inclusive leadership is emerging as a unique and critical capability helping organisations adapt to diverse customers, markets, ideas and talent. For those working around a leader, such as a manager, direct report or peer, the single most important trait generating a sense of inclusiveness is a leader’s visible awareness of bias. But to fully capitalize on their cognizance of bias, leaders also must express both humility and empathy. This article describes organizational practices that can help leaders become more inclusive and enhance the performance of their teams.

subjects.title: Using a Mantra to be a more inclusive leader
subjects.description: One of the greatest challenges facing leaders today is creating a culture of inclusiveness, where all members are treated equitably and feel equally valued. To develop truly inclusive behaviors, leaders must start by understanding the psychological mechanisms that are holding them back. Then, they can take actions — including using the “mantra” technique — to ensure their behavior has the intended impact. A mantra is a phrase that is repeated silently before entering a challenging context to focus the mind and body on a clear, unambiguous intention. The authors teach mantra as a tool to help leaders behave in a way that’s consistent with their values. Here, they offer simple steps to help leaders harness the power of mantra in creating inclusive spaces

subjects.title: How to reduce bias in your workplace
subjects.description: We all have bias -- especially the unconscious kind -- and it's preventing us from doing our best work. Gone unchecked, bias can make employees feel resentful, frustrated and silenced, and it can even lead to outright discrimination and harassment. Check out three key ways to reduce bias at work, according to Just Work cofounders Kim Scott and Trier Bryant.

subjects.title: Is it safe to speak up at work?
subjects.description: Are you afraid to share bad news, ask for help, or admit you were wrong? These are signs of being in a psychologically unsafe work environment. Adam breaks down the importance of psychological safety in preventing errors and promoting innovation and inclusion, and examines what it takes to build a culture of voice rather than silence

subjects.title: How managers create a culture of belonging
subjects.description: In this course, instructor Kimberly Manns helps you define what belonging means to you and how you can create belonging for yourself and others at your organization, using the Head, Heard, Hands framework. Kimberly discusses belonging, both within and at the organizational level, then introduces the Head, Heart, Hands (H3) framework.

categories.title: Boundary Spanning
categories.description: As leaders, we must think and act as “One Autodesk.” That means spanning boundaries to prioritize enterprise goals over functional needs.
definition: Encourages cross-silo collaboration; advocates for 'OneAutodesk' while prioritizing enterprise goals over functional needs
Co-creates the path forward by engaging others across multiple teams, functions, and/or disciplines while balancing inputs with moving decisions forward
Does not over-index on consensus, permission-seeking, or exclusive alliances

subjects.title: What is Boundary Spanning? Definition, Examples & Uses to an Organization
subjects.description: Boundary spanning is a process of developing external relationships by spanning the boundaries for the accomplishment of business objectives. It refers to a situation where an individual or an organization crosses the boundaries of a social group.

subjects.title: Boundary Spanning Leadership
subjects.description: From 2008 to 2009, the Center for Creative Leadership surveyed 128 senior executives who participated in CCL’s Leadership at the Peak program. The executives served at the senior most levels of their organizations, with more than 15 years of management experience and responsibility for at least 500 people. This survey focuses on pressing trends and challenges affecting their organizations, and the role of leadership in spanning vertical, horizontal, stakeholder, demographic, and geographic boundaries.

subjects.title: Creating a Culture of Collaboration
subjects.description: Author, CEO and instructor Lisa Bodell outlines the benefits of collaboration, and shares techniques for leaders or individual contributors to start building a team-centric culture.

subjects.title: United We Stand: Boundary Spanning Leadership
subjects.description: In this episode, we’ll discover how leaders can use Boundary Spanning Leadership to create direction, alignment, and commitment across divisions in their organizations. How do separate teams and functions work together to achieve common goals, break down barriers, and recognize differences as strengths?

subjects.title: Working on a Cross Functional Team
subjects.description: A standard functional organization encourages people to focus on their own individual tasks. Cross-functional teams, on the other hand, bring everybody together to deliver the whole product.

categories.title: Setting Strategic Vision
categories.description: Show, don’t tell. Build a shared sense of purpose by setting long- and short-term goals that connect your team’s work to Autodesk’s objectives.
definition: Builds a shared sense of purpose with individuals and teams, helping them connect their work to Autodesk's strategic objectives
Strategically sets long- and short-term goals for the organization and monitors and adjusts to increase bottom-line financials / ensure results are deliverd
Takes responsibility and ownership, ensuring people leaders have the resources needed to accomplish the work for the success of the function

subjects.title: Connecting Your Work to Your Purpose
subjects.description: In this course, author and coach Alexandra Cole shows you how to define and achieve purpose in a way that is custom-fitted to your own life. Alexandra presents a host of tools for your journey, like identifying some common blockers on your path to purpose, understanding the important difference between passion and purpose, and narrowing down to find your next best step

subjects.title: Setting Business Unit Goals
subjects.description: In this course, leadership consultant Mike Figliuolo outlines how to set different types of business goals: quantitative, qualitative, commit, and stretch goals.

subjects.title: Leading High-Performance Companies with Purpose
subjects.description: Hone the skills needed to outperform today's players and outdistance tomorrow's competitors, through Harvard Business School Executive Education.

categories.title: Creativity & Innovation
categories.description: Spark innovation by stoking creativity. Create an environment of openness and possibility that anticipates customer needs.
definition: Creates an environment that sparks, cultivates, and embraces creativity and innovation
Models openness, reception, and possibility to new ways of thinking and addressing challenges
Clarifies and anticipates customer needs to be solved for and shapes longer-term markets through testing and oprn iteration

subjects.title: Cultivating the Four Kinds of Creativity
subjects.description: In this article the authors offer a new typology that breaks creative thinking into four types: integration, or showing that two things that appear different are the same; splitting, or seeing how… One island of stability in the sea of conversation about the future of work is the conviction that our jobs will become increasingly creative.

subjects.title: How to manage for collective creativity
subjects.description: Harvard professor Linda Hill, co-author of 'Collective Genius,' has studied some of the world's most creative companies to come up with a set of tools and tactics to keep great ideas flowing -- from everyone in the company, not just the designated 'creatives.'

subjects.title: Balancing Innovation and Risk
subjects.description: Author and CEO Lisa Bodell guides you through the importance of smart risk-taking in innovation

subjects.title: Live From HIBT Summit: Payal Kadakia, Tristan Walker, and Perry Chen on Innovation
subjects.description: n this live conversation with Guy, the panel talks about how innovation doesn't require newness, but rather, authenticity. We'll be releasing more episodes from the Summit, so keep checking your podcast feed.

subjects.title: Build Your Creative Capacity as a Leader
subjects.description: In this course, instructor and creativity strategist Natalie Nixon offers a fresh approach to leadership skills development so you can be more impactful in your role.

categories.title: Influencing
categories.description: Adapt, navigate, communicate. Use these practices to influence others by building support and gaining buy-in from diverse groups.
definition: Adapts communications to build support from other and get buy-in from diverse groups
Navigates the organization effectively and influences individuals, groups, and networks
Communicates a compelling vision for solutions / recommendations

subjects.title: Getting Employee Buy-In for Organizational Change
subjects.description: Although change is never easy, how leaders approach it makes a significant difference to whether it’s embraced or rejected. By addressing the organizational buy-in context, it’s much easier to move past resistance and stagnation, because your path forward will be shaped by realities rather than banalities. The most successful organizations do this by addressing six components of culture: legitimacy, ownership, relevance, attainability, authenticity, and impartiality.

subjects.title: What makes us influential?
subjects.description: Jon Levy, a behavioral scientist who studies human activity, seeks to understand the power of influence in today's connected world. In this talk, Levy shares how he personally connects some of the world's most influential people, by simply inviting them to a dinner party.

subjects.title: The 10 Essentials of Influence and Persuasion
subjects.description: In today's fast paced, constantly changing workplace, so much of our success comes down to our ability to influence colleagues, persuade co-workers, and get clients and customers to say yes to our ideas, proposals, and requests.

subjects.title: Executive Influence
subjects.description: In this course, John Ullmen details the concept of executive influence.

subjects.title: Influence is Good
subjects.description: This report is part of a series exploring how to limit suffering, promote flourishing, and minimize risk today and in the future through systemic change.

categories.title: Building Talent
categories.description: Make good even better. Take your team, and team members, to the next level through coaching, development opportunities, and talent sharing.
definition: Coaches and sponsors people to enhance their perspective and to build their careers
Creates development opportunities to build internal talent
Facilitates stretch opportunities and sharing of talent across the organization to maintain their competitive advantage

subjects.title: How to Attract Top Talent in 2022
subjects.description: A seismic change in how people view work and the meaning work brings to their lives has created the biggest talent crisis in recent history.

subjects.title: Human capital at work: The value of experience
subjects.description: Human capital represents two-thirds of wealth for the average individual—and work experience contributes almost half of that value.

subjects.title: Coach Your Team to Learn, Stretch, and Grow
subjects.description: Learn why employee growth is so fundamental for advancement, how strong leaders can identify and develop top talent, and what an organization stands to gain from increased employee loyalty.

subjects.title: Developing Your Team Members
subjects.description: In this course, Mike Figliuolo shares a practical approach that can help you address the unique needs of your team members and determine how to best allocate your time in their development.

categories.title: Business Impact
categories.description: Bring your top game to our bottom line. Make an impact through new products and services, budget stewardship, commercial acumen, and more.
definition: Delivers growth / profit and value in the business from investments, new products, and sevices
Models stewardship of Autodesk budgets / resources through prioritization, driving efficiencies, and delivering cost savings
Demonstrates strong commercial acumen by aligning investments to impactful areas for customers and / or Autodesk

subjects.title: Level Up Your Leaders
subjects.description: Work, fast-tracked into the future In recent years, one adage has reverberated from boardrooms to business headlines: 'Future-proof your organization.'

subjects.title: Building a Finance Function That Drives
subjects.description: Geopolitical uncertainty, supply chain challenges, and issues related to cash flow and revenue streams in recent years have increased the workloads and raised the profile of finance departments within organizations.

subjects.title: The ten rules of growth
subjects.description: One of the surest signs of a thriving enterprise is robust and consistent revenue growth. That has not been easy to accomplish over the past 15 years.

subjects.title: Designing Growth Strategies
subjects.description: University of Maryland Professor Anil Gupta emphasizes the necessity of business growth for talent retention, competitive advantage, and shareholder value, based on his experience with high-growth tech ventures and major corporations. He presents a framework for identifying and implementing high-potential growth strategies, and addresses the organizational and leadership prerequisites for fostering a high-growth company.

subjects.title: Managerial Economics
subjects.description: To understand what managerial economics looks like in practice, Stefan explains how Google's auction-based advertising system employs the principles of game theory and how understanding this can help decision makers to outmaneuver their competitors.

subjects.title: Trusted Partner Leadership Intention Workshop
subjects.description: Through reflective activities and open discussions, attendees will explore the intricacies of trust-building, identify personal trust anchors and wobbles, and strategize ways to authentically model trust-centric behaviors across diverse team settings.

subjects.title: Begin with Trust
subjects.description: This article explains how leaders can identify their weaknesses and strengths on these three dimensions and offers advice on how all three can be developed in the service of a truly empowering leadership style.

subjects.description: In this article, learn to recognize that failure is inevitable in today's complex work organizations, however some failures are even good. Successful learning from failure is not simple: It requires context-specific strategies. First leaders must understand how the blame game gets in the way and must work to create an organizational culture in which employees feel safe admitting or reporting on failure.  Learn about the different types of failures and how to learn from each.

subjects.title: Special Issue: How to Build Trust (Skill Path)
subjects.description: Dive into this MyLearning skill plan on building trust. Learn more about how to cultivate relationships with customers and colleagues, win over skeptics, and inspire others through these curated resources.

subjects.description: The article underscores the need for flexible strategic planning in organizations, comparing it to sailing and suggesting practices like defining an Essential Intent, setting strategic trade-offs, and identifying 90-day outcomes. It concludes by advocating for organizations to operate as adaptable fleets rather than large, inflexible cruise ships.
